entry.et: Middle English, from Anglo-French observer, from Latin observare to guard, watch, observe, from ob- in the way, toward + servare to keep conserve

def.dt: :to conform one's action or practice to (as a law, rite, or condition) :comply with
:to inspect or take note of as an augury, omen, or presage
:to celebrate or solemnize (as a ceremony or festival) in a customary or accepted way
:to watch carefully especially with attention to details or behavior for the purpose of arriving at a judgment
:to make a scientific observation on or of
:to come to realize or know especially through consideration of noted facts
